question: A 28-year-old male presents with a recent onset of upsetting dreams, anxiety, and disturbing flashbacks. The patient reports that he returned from active duty in Iraq 3 months ago and was adjusting to life back at home until about 7 weeks ago when he began having intense fear of loud noises and seeing sudden flashbacks to bombing attacks he endured during his time in Iraq. He had to take a leave from his army instructor duties as he was not able to handle the familiar settings of practice shooting ranges and sudden loud explosions during battalion training. After refusing to leave his house, he was finally persuaded by his wife to visit your clinic. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The symptoms of intense fear of loud noises and seeing sudden flashbacks to bombing attacks are also characteristic of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The duration of the symptoms, which started about 7 weeks ago, also supports a diagnosis of PTSD. The patient's symptoms do not appear to be a panic attack, as they are not described as episodic and are not limited to a specific situation. Performance anxiety is also not a good fit, as the patient's symptoms are not related to a specific performance or situation. Acute stress disorder is also not a good fit, as the duration of the symptoms is longer than the typical duration of acute stress disorder. The reaction may occur shortly after the trauma (acute stress disorder) or be delayed and subject to recurrence (PTSD) (Table 466-6). In both syndromes, individuals experience associated symptoms of detachment and loss of emotional responsivity. The patient may feel depersonalized and unable to recall specific aspects of the trauma, although typically it is reexperienced through intrusions in thought, dreams, or flashbacks, particularly when cues of the original event are present. Patients often actively avoid stimuli that precipitate recollections of the trauma and demonstrate a resulting increase in vigilance, arousal, and startle response.
